captions.text:
PRE-SEASON TRAINING
SPEED
Speed is a fundamental part of football

CRAIG TURNER
SPORTS SCIENTIST
A lot of match actions are decided by that split second by whether you can get that ball before your opponent
A lot of goals are scored after a sprint into the box - big explosive headers
So it's massively important in the game
We try and implement individual conditioning
But also implement different varieties of speed drills
The first drill focuses more on repetitive sprint ability
So it's a little bit shorter in distance, and a little bit shorter duration rest time
Team one will be on that side, team two on that side
You start on the cone
Man versus man
You're sprinting out to the ball
You play it first time, you are aiming for the mini goal
If you get it in, you get a point
And then it's a race to finish through the poles
When you race, you also get a point
Go
We are trying to get that high intensity burst, a little bit of rest, high intensity burst again, mimicking those abilities within football
Two sets of around about six to eight runs
It's nice and easy and take four minutes between each set just to recuperate all the energy systems as well
Okay boys so this is our speed testing component
It is a 40 meter sprint in total,
what will be recording is your 5 metter time, your 10 meter time, 20 meter time and 40 meter time
Within that 5 meter stage you're looking for being under one second
building into the 20 meter, a time under 3 seconds, thats very quick.

CURTIS HANSFORD
FULLBACK
The high end, the 40 meter anything below 5.4 you're particularly quick, you'll probably get to a good high max speed

BEN PARTRIDGE
WINGER
we'll start looking at how that player is accelerating,
Where his arm and his leg position are
Is he getting a nice high knee,
toe pointed up,
arm up 90 degrees,
overarm back nice and straight,
then you can start working and refining that weakness but also you can work out what strength they've got.
So if somebody is very quick at getting to max speed, a very fast accelerator,
then you want to make that better, you want to refine and develop that talent
5.35, pre-season is your developmental stage, so within that were looking to overload the lads,
make sure they get an improvement so when they get into in season
we can just do speed maintenance work and keep them at a high level

comments.text:
Theo Walcott hits a 4.72 seconds in 2009, and could probably run slightly 
faster now﻿
comments.author: Oliver Douglas

comments.text:
Logged in because people are full of crap. 5m time of 1.00 or under is 
quick. 0.90 is very fast. That's like messi quickness with a 5.5m/s 
acceleration. 
10m time of average pro's is 1.7ish. Don't forget this is electronic and 
not handheld. You could add anything to 0.24 to your time and that might be 
what you would get electronically.
20m 3.00 is basic for pro's. 2.95 is a average. 2.82 is fast. 2.6-2.7 is 
elite
40m, get under 5.00 and you have speed. Henry's time was 4.85 while vela 
and toure got under 4.95. Get 4.8 and your doing a 4.4 40 yard dash.
Also do electronic timing. If you guys were as quick as you think. You 
would literally run through everyone in your league. Carragher was running 
sub 3.00 20m and you guys thought he was slow﻿

comments.author: Andew GFX

comments.text:
100 metre sprint times:
Abou Bourne - Central Midfielder: 5.32 secs (40m)  minus 3.01 secs (20m) = 
2.31 secs
So... 3.01 secs is his time for the initial 20 metres, whereas 2.31 secs is 
his time over 20 metres at full speed. 3.01 (20m  (start)) + 2.31 ((20m 
(full sprint)) + 2.31 ((20m (full sprint)) + 2.31 ((20m (full sprint)) 
+ 2.31 ((20m (full sprint)) = 12.25 seconds (100m)
Abou Boune runs the 100 metres in 12.25 seconds.
  ﻿

comments.text:
Abou Bourne runs the 100m sprint in 12.25 seconds. That's 1.25 secs slower 
than Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain. 1.25 times 7 = 8.75. 89 PACE minus 8.75 PACE 
= 80 PACE (ROUNDED)
comments.author: Jasey James

comments.text:
#FIFA14ULTIMATETEAMPACE  
Theo Walcott:
PACE: 96 / 99
100m time: 10.5 seconds 
Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain:
PACE: 89 / 99
100m time: 11.5 seconds
1 second is the difference between their 100m times and that equals 7 PACE 
difference in FUT.

comments.text:
Ben Partridge - Winger: 4.93 secs (40m)  minus 2.77 secs (20m) = 2.16 secs
So... 2.77 secs is his time for the initial 20 metres, whereas 2.16 secs is 
his time over 20 metres at full speed. 2.77 (20m  (start)) + 2.16 (20m 
(full sprint)) + 2.16 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.16 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.16 
(20m (full sprint)) = 11.41 (100m) Ben Partridge runs the 100 metres 
in 11.41 seconds.

comments.text:

secs

his time over 20 metres at full speed. 3.02 (20m  (start)) + 2.42 (20m 
(full sprint)) + 2.42 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.42 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.42 
(20m (full sprint)) = 12.7 (100m) 
Curtis Hansford runs the 100 metres in 12.7 seconds.

Lee atentamente esta oración y haz lo que te dice sin ignorar los pasos que 
te pide seguir, porque si no solo obtendrás los resultados contrarios de lo 
que pidas . Piensa en la persona con la que quieres estar y di su nombre 
para ti 3 veces. Piensa en lo que quieres que ocurra con esta persona en la 
siguiente semana y repítelo para ti 6 veces. Ahora piensa en lo que quieres 
con esa persona y dilo una vez. y ahora di.. Rayo de luz yo te invoco para 
que desentierres a nombre de la persona de donde este o con quien este y le 
hagas llamarme hoy mismo enamorado y arrepentido. Desentierra todo lo que 
esta impidiendo que su nombre venga a mi nuestro nombre. Aparta a todos los 
que contribuyan a que nos apartemos y que el no piense mas en otras mujeres 
que solo piense en mi nuestro nombre Que el me llame y me ame. gracias, 
gracias por tu misterioso poder que siempre cumple con lo que se le pide.

comments.text:
+APG Eagle Eye Take that back, 11.2 seconds is impressive but 40 meters in 
4.6 seconds is faster than Theo Walcott, and he does 10.6 seconds in the 
100. It's definitely 40 yards. Bolt, Blake and Gatlin would all do under 
4.65 seconds for 40 meters, unless you think you're faster than them you're 
delusional.
comments.author: Oliver Douglas

comments.text:
+APG Eagle Eye +Rolling Kneebar Agreed with you, in the states it's 
generally 40 yards 99.9% of the time. And 4.6 seconds for 40 meters is 
insanely fast. Especially when you said at 15 your 100 was not even 11 
seconds. The average footballer would be 4.90-5.10 seconds for the 40 YARD 
dash. A quick footballer would do under 4.70 seconds, and the fastest would 
be <4.40 seconds like Theo Walcott, Mathis Bolly and Aubameyang.
comments.author: Oliver Douglas

comments.text:
APG I almost guarantee you that you ran a 40 yard sprint and not a 40 
meter, especially because you live stateside. While the difference between 
one yard and one meter is negligible, 40 yard will give you a slightly 
faster time than 40 meters.

comments.text:
+APG Eagle Eye I worked out these guy' times over the 100 metres by the way.
#SPEEDMATTERS  
100 metre sprint times:
Abou Bourne - Central Midfielder: 5.32 secs (40m)  minus 3.01 secs (20m) = 
2.31 secs
So... 3.01 secs is his time for the initial 20 metres, whereas 2.31 secs is 
his time over 20 metres at full speed. 3.01 (20m  (start)) + 2.31 ((20m 
(full sprint)) + 2.31 ((20m (full sprint)) + 2.31 ((20m (full sprint)) 
+ 2.31 ((20m (full sprint)) = 12.25 seconds (100m)
Abou Boune runs the 100 metres in 12.25 seconds. 
Curtis Hansford - Fullback: 5.44 secs (40m)  minus 3.02 secs (20m) = 2.42 
secs
So... 3.02 secs is his time for the initial 20 metres, whereas 2.42 secs is 
his time over 20 metres at full speed. 3.02 (20m  (start)) + 2.42 (20m 
(full sprint)) + 2.42 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.42 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.42 
(20m (full sprint)) = 12.7 (100m) 
Curtis Hansford runs the 100 metres in 12.7 seconds.
 
Ben Partridge - Winger: 4.93 secs (40m)  minus 2.77 secs (20m) = 2.16 secs
So... 2.77 secs is his time for the initial 20 metres, whereas 2.16 secs is 
his time over 20 metres at full speed. 2.77 (20m  (start)) + 2.16 (20m 
(full sprint)) + 2.16 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.16 (20m (full sprint)) + 2.16 
(20m (full sprint)) = 11.41 (100m) 
Ben Partridge runs the 100 metres in 11.41 seconds.
comments.author: Jasey James

comments.text:

better than average, but nothing fast ever. In football the most important 
speed is over 0-20 metres. These guys times are pretty average for 
footballers as it doesn't include reaction time. I was slow when i was your 
age 15.6s  i had a poor start and still do but a strong finish. But i was a 
Goalkeeper and did no form of running whatsoever. Now, I play outfield 15 
years 3 months, never been timed but alot faster, I run at a club too, so 
i'd say i do 12.5 seconds.
